user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_response_element_n_:
```c
struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *
MHD_get_response_element_n_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                             enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                             const char *key,
                             size_t key_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  mhd_assert (NULL != key);
  mhd_assert (0 != key[0]);
  mhd_assert (0 != key_len);

  for (pos = response->first_header;
       NULL != pos;
       pos = pos->next)
  {
    if ((pos->header_size == key_len) &&
        (kind == pos->kind) &&
        (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (pos->header, key, pos->header_size)))
      return pos;
  }
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if ((pos->header_size == key_len) &&
        (kind == pos->kind) &&
        (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (pos->header, key, pos->header_size)))
      return pos;
explanation: MISRA C Rule 21.17 concerns use of <string.h> functions (memcpy, memcmp, strlen, etc.) that may access beyond object bounds. The only site in this function that could invoke such string handling operations is the call to MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_. That call uses three pointers/lengths (pos->header, key, pos->header_size / key_len) and the surrounding code does not validate that the memory for 'key' covers 'key_len' bytes nor that 'pos->header' covers 'pos->header_size' bytes. The three mhd_assert checks present only verify that key is non-NULL, that its first character is non-zero, and that key_len is non-zero; they do not guarantee the buffers are at least key_len bytes long, so these assertions are relevant to investigate. Other fragments of the function (the for-loop control, the return NULL, function signature, variable declaration) do not perform or initiate string handling and thus are not relevant to Rule 21.17 and do not need investigation in this context.
